Title: Tibial Bone Remodeling with Total Knee Arthroplasty: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Background: Tibial bone remodeling following total knee arthroplasty (TKA) and its clinical implications remain unclear. This study aimed to compare tibial bone density changes in cemented TKA components with different bearing designs.

Methods: We conducted a randomised controlled trial with 54 participants, randomised to receive either rotating-platform (n=28) or fixed-platform (n=26) cemented TKA. The study was conducted at [study setting]. Eligibility criteria included [participant eligibility criteria]. Bone density changes were assessed using quantitative computed tomography (qCT)-assisted osteodensitometry. The nonoperated contralateral side served as a control. CT scans were performed postoperatively and at 1 and 2 years. Randomisation was achieved using [randomisation method] with allocation concealment via [allocation concealment method]. Blinding was applied to [outcome assessors/patients/clinicians].

Results: Cancellous bone density loss was observed in all proximal tibial regions in both cohorts, with a maximum loss of 12.6% at 2 years. Cortical bone density loss was lower, with a maximum of 3.6% at 2 years. No significant differences in bone loss were found between the fixed- and rotating-platform implants. The analysis was conducted using [analysis approach]. No adverse events were reported.

Interpretation: The decrease in cancellous bone density after TKA suggests stress transfer to the cortical bone. Further research is needed to understand the clinical implications of these findings.
